Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Tritube vs. Microlaryngeal Tube in Laryngeal Surgery

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomly allocated to either the Tritube-FCV group or the MLT-VCV group.

Participants.evidence: 55 patients over 18 years were assessed, with 40 included in the analysis. Eligibility criteria included elective laryngeal surgery, excluding those with ASA status >III, planned laser surgery, or COPD >GOLD II.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomly allocated to either the Tritube-FCV group or the MLT-VCV group.

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial assessed whether a Tritube with flow-controlled ventilation (FCV) improves laryngeal visibility and surgical conditions compared to a conventional microlaryngeal tube (MLT) with volume-controlled ventilation (VCV) during elective laryngeal surgery.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the concealment of laryngeal structures, measured immediately post-intubation.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated in blocks of 10, with allocation concealed in closed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was not possible due to visible differences in tubes.

Number_Randomised.evidence: From October 2017 to May 2018, 20 patients were randomised to each group.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The Tritube group showed significantly less laryngeal concealment (7% [6 to 9]) compared to the MLT group (22% [18 to 27], p < 0.001).
